patterns: How should I secure my laptop?
What are the laptop security guidelines?
How can I prevent laptop theft?
What should I do to protect my laptop?
responses: Company laptops must be secured at all times to prevent loss of the computer and sensitive information.
Report the loss of any laptop immediately to the IT department to reset all passwords and notify HR/Admin.
Each laptop owner is responsible for taking appropriate measures to protect their laptop.
Here are some suggestions to reduce the chances of theft, damage, or disclosure:
- Laptop computers should not be left in an unsecured office or on a desktop when leaving work. Take it with you or secure it in a lockable office or drawer.
- When going through airport security, place your laptop on the x-ray belt just before stepping through. Do not allow others to cut ahead.
- Keep your laptop out of sight inside a vehicle; store it in the trunk when unattended.
- Carry your laptop with you when checking into a hotel. Do not leave it in your room in plain sight; store it in a drawer or take it with you.
- Always be aware of the location of your laptop.
- Routinely back up critical data files to a network drive or backup device.

patterns: What are the password policy requirements?
What is the minimum password length?
How often do I need to change my password?
What is the account lockout threshold?
What happens after too many invalid login attempts?
What is the password history requirement?
When should default accounts be deleted or renamed?
responses: All domains must adhere to the following account policy settings:
- Minimum Password Length: 6 characters
- Maximum Password Age: 90 days
- Minimum Password Age: 1 day
- Enforce Password History: 4 passwords
- Account Lockout Threshold: 3 invalid login attempts
- Reset Account Lockout Counter after 30 minutes
- Account Lockout Duration: 30 minutes
Default accounts in the domain must be deleted or renamed before the first system is placed into production.

patterns: What are the rules for user IDs?
How often should passwords be changed?
Can users change their own passwords?
What happens if I forget my password?
What should I do if my user ID is compromised?
When should user IDs be disabled or removed?
What are the rules for transmitting passwords?
How is access managed during employee changes?
responses: Here are the user identification and password guidelines:
- Computerized systems should allow users to change their own passwords.
- Password standards include:
- Minimum length of 6 characters.
- Password change every 90 days.
- Must include three of these four character types: upper-case alphabetic, lower-case alphabetic, numeric, or special characters ($! %*).
- Must not be the same as user ID, displayed in clear text, or stored in unencrypted format.
- Must not be printed on system reports or easily guessable.
- Must not be 'Guest', 'Secret', 'Password', or dictionary words.
- User IDs and passwords must not be transmitted in clear text for GROZ systems accessible via non-GROZ networks.
- Network and System Administrators should not have access to user passwords.
- Positive verification is required for all password resets.
- Users cannot reuse a password within 6 cycles of changing it.
- User IDs must be disabled after 6 unsuccessful access attempts or for illegal activity.
- User IDs and passwords must not be hard coded or embedded into software.
- Users must be notified of the last time their user ID was used, and discrepancies should be reported.
- Access to computer resources must be canceled upon termination or change in employment status.
- Procedures to bypass identification and verification routines are not permitted.
- Security administrators must not provide unapproved access; access must be granted by the data owner or supervisor.

patterns: What are the virus protection rules?
Can you list the virus protection guidelines?
Tell me the rules for virus protection
responses:
Here are the virus protection rules:

a. Licensed anti-virus software must be installed and operational on all stand-alone or networked computer systems.
b. Anti-virus software pattern files must be kept current. The pattern files must be updated within one day after release of a new virus definition file being made available from the anti-virus software manufacturer.
c. All anti-virus reports will be reviewed on a monthly basis to determine if software is up-to-date and performing as expected.
d. All servers must be set up to run the real-time scanner, scanning files written to disk.
e. Report all virus infections to the help desk supporting your location. Send email notification to IT Security & Compliance.
f. Workstations must be configured to run the real-time scanner, scanning at least files written to disk.
g. All removable media, regardless of where it comes from, must be scanned for viruses before it is used. This includes but is not limited to; demonstration software, shrink wrapped software, diskettes/CDs/DVDs, USB storage devices, digital cameras, or any other device that contains files that are added or inserted into a computer system.
h. Digital media intended for mass distribution must be validated to be free from viruses prior to distribution.
i. Following the repair of a computer system, the equipment must be validated to be free from viruses before it’s connected to the network.
j. Business critical, important or sensitive data files must be stored on network drives.
k. Users should be prevented from modifying executable files on servers. This aids in preventing a user’s workstation from infecting a file server.
l. Infected systems must be promptly removed from the network and thereafter an engineer will deep scan the system.
m. During office hours, no one may unplug their system to support System scanning activity. If so, then they will be solely responsible for data loss due to a VIRUS. (Based upon failure, the IT department will generate a periodic report of this and share with the respective HOD).
